00027 #define BAUD_RATE 57600
00028 
00029 ///  LETARTARE 20/04/2014
00030 // Default cpu mappings. this Grbl supports the Arduino MEGA2560 only. Other processor types
00031 // may exist from user-supplied templates or directly user-defined in cpu_map.h
00032 #define PIN_MAP_ARDUINO_MEGA_2560  // Arduino Mega2560r3
00033 
00034 /// 843 : 20/04/2014
00035 // Default settings. Used when resetting EEPROM. Change to desired name in defaults.h
00036 #define DEFAULTS_LETARTARE
00037 
00038 #include "pin_map.h"
00039 /// <--
00040 
00041 // Define runtime command special characters. These characters are 'picked-off' directly from the
00042 // serial read data stream and are not passed to the grbl line execution parser. Select characters
00043 // that do not and must not exist in the streamed g-code program. ASCII control characters may be
00044 // used, if they are available per user setup. Also, extended ASCII codes (>127), which are never in
00045 // g-code programs, maybe selected for interface programs.
00046 // TODO: Solidify these default characters. Temporary for now.
00047 #define CMD_STATUS_REPORT '?'
00048 #define CMD_FEED_HOLD '!'
00049 #define CMD_CYCLE_START '~'
00050 #define CMD_RESET 0x18 // ctrl-x
00051 
00052 // Specifies the number of work coordinate systems grbl will support (G54 - G59).
00053 // This parameter must be one or greater, currently supporting up to a value of 6.
00054 #define N_COORDINATE_SYSTEM 1
00055 
00056 // This parameter sets the delay time before disabling the steppers after the final block of movement.
00057 // A short delay ensures the steppers come to a complete stop and the residual inertial force in the
00058 // CNC axes don't cause the axes to drift off position. This is particularly important when manually
00059 // entering g-code into grbl, i.e. locating part zero or simple manual machining. If the axes drift,
00060 // grbl has no way to know this has happened, since stepper motors are open-loop control. Depending
00061 // on the machine, this parameter may need to be larger or smaller than the default time.
00062 // NOTE: If set to zero, the delay will not be compiled.
00063 #define STEPPER_IDLE_LOCK_TIME 25 // (milliseconds) - Integer > 0
00064 
00065 // The temporal resolution of the acceleration management subsystem. Higher number give smoother
00066 // acceleration but may impact performance.
00067 // NOTE: Increasing this parameter will help any resolution related issues, especially with machines
00068 // requiring very high accelerations and/or very fast feedrates. In general, this will reduce the
00069 // error between how the planner plans the motions and how the stepper program actually performs them.
00070 // However, at some point, the resolution can be high enough, where the errors related to numerical
00071 // round-off can be great enough to cause problems and/or it's too fast for the Arduino. The correct
00072 // value for this parameter is machine dependent, so it's advised to set this only as high as needed.
00073 // Approximate successful values can range from 30L to 100L or more.
00074 #define ACCELERATION_TICKS_PER_SECOND 50L
00075 
00076 // Minimum planner junction speed. Sets the default minimum speed the planner plans for at the end
00077 // of the buffer and all stops. This should not be much greater than zero and should only be changed
00078 // if unwanted behavior is observed on a user's machine when running at very slow speeds.
00079 #define MINIMUM_PLANNER_SPEED 0.0 // (mm/min)
00080 
00081 // Minimum stepper rate. Sets the absolute minimum stepper rate in the stepper program and never runs
00082 // slower than this value, except when sleeping. This parameter overrides the minimum planner speed.
00083 // This is primarily used to guarantee that the end of a movement is always reached and not stop to
00084 // never reach its target. This parameter should always be greater than zero.
00085 #define MINIMUM_STEPS_PER_MINUTE 800 // (steps/min) - Integer value only
00086 
00087 // Number of arc generation iterations by small angle approximation before exact arc trajectory
00088 // correction. This parameter maybe decreased if there are issues with the accuracy of the arc
00089 // generations. In general, the default value is more than enough for the intended CNC applications
00090 // of grbl, and should be on the order or greater than the size of the buffer to help with the
00091 // computational efficiency of generating arcs.
00092 #define N_ARC_CORRECTION 40 // Integer (1-255)
00093 
00094 // Time delay increments performed during a dwell. The default value is set at 50ms, which provides
00095 // a maximum time delay of roughly 55 minutes, more than enough for most any application. Increasing
00096 // this delay will increase the maximum dwell time linearly, but also reduces the responsiveness of
00097 // run-time command executions, like status reports, since these are performed between each dwell
00098 // time step. Also, keep in mind that the Arduino delay timer is not very accurate for long delays.
00099 #define DWELL_TIME_STEP 50 // Integer (1-255) (milliseconds)
00100 
00101 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00102 // FOR ADVANCED USERS ONLY:
00103 
00104 // Toggles XON/XOFF software flow control for serial communications. Not officially supported
00105 // due to problems involving the Atmega8U2 USB-to-serial chips on current Arduinos. The firmware
00106 // on these chips do not support XON/XOFF flow control characters and the intermediate buffer
00107 // in the chips cause latency and overflow problems with standard terminal programs. However,
00108 // using specifically-programmed UI's to manage this latency problem has been confirmed to work.
00109 // As well as, older FTDI FT232RL-based Arduinos(Duemilanove) are known to work with standard
00110 // terminal programs since their firmware correctly manage these XON/XOFF characters. In any
00111 // case, please report any successes to grbl administrators!
00112 // #define ENABLE_XONXOFF 0 // Boolean. Default disabled.
00113 
00114 // Creates a delay between the direction pin setting and corresponding step pulse by creating
00115 // another interrupt (Timer2 compare) to manage it. The main Grbl interrupt (Timer1 compare)
00116 // sets the direction pins, and does not immediately set the stepper pins, as it would in
00117 // normal operation. The Timer2 compare fires next to set the stepper pins after the step
00118 // pulse delay time, and Timer2 overflow will complete the step pulse, except now delayed
00119 // by the step pulse time plus the step pulse delay. (Thanks langwadt for the idea!)
00120 //   This is an experimental feature that should only be used if your setup requires a longer
00121 // delay between direction and step pin settings (some opto coupler based drivers), as it may
00122 // adversely effect Grbl's high-end performance (>10kHz). Please notify Grbl administrators
00123 // of your successes or difficulties, as we will monitor this and possibly integrate this as a
00124 // standard feature for future releases. However, we suggest to first try our direction delay
00125 // hack/solution posted in the Wiki involving inverting the stepper pin mask.
00126 // NOTE: If set greater than zero, step pulse delay will be compiled and enabled. Also, the
00127 // total delay added with the Grbl settings pulse microseconds must not exceed 127 ms.
00128 // #define STEP_PULSE_DELAY 0 // Step pulse delay in microseconds. Default disabled.
00129 
00130 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00131

00133 // settings version has solidified.
00134 #define CYCLE_AUTO_START 1    // Cycle auto-start boolean flag for the planner.
00135 #define BLOCK_DELETE_ENABLE 0 // Block delete enable/disable flag during g-code parsing
00136 #define REPORT_INCH_MODE 0    // Status reporting unit mode (1 = inch, 0 = mm)
00137 #if REPORT_INCH_MODE
00138   #define DECIMAL_PLACES 3
00139   #define DECIMAL_MULTIPLIER 1000 // 10^DECIMAL_PLACES
00140 #else
00141   #define DECIMAL_PLACES 2  // mm-mode
00142   #define DECIMAL_MULTIPLIER 100
00143 #endif
